Table 2 Image, table 1 Image, table 1 Image, table 1 Image, table 1 Image, table 1 Catalytic chemo and homoselective ipso-nitration under mild condition Hassan Sepehrmansourie a Mahmoud Zarei a ⁎ Mohammad Ali Zolfigol a ⁎ Sima Kalhor a Hu Shi b a Department of Organic Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, Bu-Ali Sina University, Hamedan 6517838683, Iran Department of Organic Chemistry Faculty of Chemistry Bu-Ali Sina University Hamedan 6517838683 Iran aDepartment of Organic Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, Bu-Ali Sina University, Hamedan 6517838683, Iran b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Institute of Molecular Science, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Institute of Molecular Science Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China bSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Institute of Molecular Science, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A new selective nitration methodology is reported in which MOFs/sodium nitrite is used. A wide range of compounds such as boronic acids, aryl halides, aryl trifluoromethanesulfonate and aroyl chlorides were nitrated in the presence of a catalytic amount of palladium (Pd) embedded into MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 as a porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The described method provides a beneficial and convenient strategy for chemo and homoselective ipso-nitration reaction. In contrast to the previously reported methodologies, acid nitric (HNO3) was not used in the course of the nitration reaction. The presented method was applied for the ipso-nitration of a broad range of compounds (47 samples) under mild conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Chemoselective reaction Homoselective reaction Ipso-nitration Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) Nitration Nitro compound Data Availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Nowadays, crystal engineering and one of their major categories metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are in a great demand in a broad range of science [1-3]. This structure could be considered as catalyst, gas separation, oxidative, adsorption and drug delivery [4–8]. MOFs, due to high thermal stability and surface area, have been widely applied as catalyst in various functional group transformations such as coupling, multi-component, and oxidation reactions [9–20]. The post-modification strategy is a new facile design and preparation of MOFs based on Cr nuclei for the preparation of organic compounds [21-25]. There with, potential functionalization and post-modification of MOFs have represented the mystery of researcher groups in organic chemistry [26,27]. Among them is, encapsulation of an active guest as a highly convenient strategy to reach properties beyond those of MOFs architectures [28]. These frameworks provide better access to the pores ensuring an ensure optimal diffusion of the material while providing a unique scaffold that inhibits the accumulation and lubrication of active guests and ensures a strong interaction between core and shell, which leads to the same effects. Metal and/or NPs are embedded into metal-organic frameworks as a new strategy for the presentation of post-modification MOFs [29,30]. Selective nitration reaction is a well-established ipso strategy for the preparation of high-value nitro compounds (aromatic and olefin). This new strategy is widely used in the production of drugs, dyes, plastics, intermediate materials and explosive compounds [31–46]. This method is a useful approach for CNO2 bond formation via deactivated bond of carbonyl, halogen (I, Br and Cl), hydroxyl and boronic acid, in which a variety of nitro materials (aromatic and olefin) is prepared [47–50]. Generally, catalytic nitration reactions that have been applied on metals, salts, and ionic liquids, are performed in the presence of various nitrating agents, cocatalysts and solvents with low yields and high temperature [51–58]. Although nitration is a famous reaction in organic chemistry, it has a troublesome reaction condition such as (i) over nitration harmful solvent, (ii) the lack of a need for additional chemical reagents such as oxidizing, reducing agents and acid nitric (HNO3), (iii) the use of toxic reagent (iv) high regioselectivity and (v) the environmental friendliness. Previous synthetic strategies of nitration reaction are mainly based on the directing group to generate the mixture products (ortho, meta and para). The previously reported methods generally suffer from low ortho/meta/para site-selectivity (Scheme 1 ). Therefore, designing an effective, cheap, nontoxic, and versatile source for the chemo and homoselective ipso-nitration reaction is still an urgent need. In continuation of development of nitration methodologies [54,59], we have introduced palladium (Pd) embedded into MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 as a new porous hybrid metal-organic frameworks, namely MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 as a catalyst with special emphasis on architectonic methods and synergistic roles. This novel strategy proceeds on the basis of the selective activation of the C-X (X= OH, CO2H, B(OH)2, Cl, Br and I) bond of both aromatic and olefin compounds. In this paper, we disclose the first palladium-catalyzed based on MOFs for the preparation of high-value nitro compounds with high yields (47 samples) via traditional ipso-nitration reaction (Scheme 2 ). Experimental Produced of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 On the basis of the previously reported procedure [14], a mixture of BDCNH2 (4 mmol, 0.724 g), Cr(NO3)3·9(H2O) (4 mmol, 1.6 g), and NaOH (10 mmol, 0.4 g) were dispersed in water (20 mL) for 10 min. Then, the reaction mixture was kept at 150 °C for 12 h in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. After cooling the reaction mixture, the green residue was washed with water and the corresponding precipitate obtained. Finally, the desired solid was dried at 80 °C within a vacuum oven for 12 h (Scheme 3 ). Produced of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) On the basis of the previously reported procedure [60], after the synthesis of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2, 0.5 g of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 and CH3CN (30 mL) were mixed and stirred for 30 min at 25 °C. Then, 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (PC) (3 mmol, 0.321 g) was added to the reaction mixture, and the resultant solution stirred at 40–45 °C for 48 h. The desired residue was washed with ethanol for two times and the desired product MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) was obtained via filtration (Scheme 3). Produced of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 as new metal-organic frameworks On the basis of the previously reported procedure [61], in 10 mL round-bottomed flask a mixture of PdCl2 (0.5 mmol) and MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) (1 g) in toluene and DMF (1:1, 5 mL) as solvent was heated at 80 °C for 2 h. Then, the reaction mixture was cooled up to room temperature. Thereafter, the MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 was filtered using a centrifugation (1000 rpm) and dried under vacuum at 60 °C (Scheme 3). General method for the ipso-nitration reaction using MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 /NaNO2 as new nitrating agent Aroyl chlorides and aryl trifluoromethanesulfonate were prepared according to the previously reported methods [62,63]. Then, in a 10 mL round-bottomed flask, a mixture of aryl derivatives (boronic acids, chlorides, halides or trifluoromethanesulfonate) (1 mmol), NaNO2 (3 mmol), tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) (20 mol%), MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 as catalyst (5 mg) and n-butanol solvent (5 mL) were stirred under the reflux condition for appropriate time according to Table 2. Progress of the reaction was followed by using TLC technique. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated from mixture by using centrifuged (1000 rpm, 5 min). Then, the pure nitro material was purified by plate chromatography (n-hexane: ethyl acetate 4:1) (Scheme 2). Result and discussion In order to expand a novel method for ipso-nitration of organic compounds, we have presentenced a novel MOFs namely MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 as a metal-organic frameworks (Scheme 3). The structure of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 was verified by FT-IR, XRD, EDX, SEM-elemental mapping, SEM, TEM and BET/BJH. Then, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) containing palladium (Pd) with NaNO2 were applied for the ipso-nitration reaction such as Ar-X derivatives (X: B(OH)2, OTf, halogens (I, Br, Cl) and COCl) (Scheme 2). The comparison FT-IR spectrum of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2, MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) and MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 are shown in Fig. 1 . As notched Fig. 1, the aromatic CH and C=C stretches bands are, respectively, at 3054 and 1572 cm–1. The observation peak at 1680 cm–1 confirmed C=N double bond. The band at 1678 cm–1 due to C=N double bond reaction with Pd shifted to lower frequency. Besides, the observation peak at 588 cm–1 confirmed Pd-N in catalyst. A comparison of FT-IR spectra between starting materials and MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 verified the structure of the catalyst. In another study, the shape and morphology of catalyst and starting materials were compared by XRD at the range of 5–80° as Fig. 2 . The peaks of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 corresponded to reported literature survey [[64,65]. These peaks are shown in catalyst and MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC), respectively. Besides, XRD patterns lines of high crystalline at 2θ = 38.25°, 48.65° and 68.80° corresponded to Pd in MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 diffraction lines (111), (200) and (220) [66]. In another technique, the elemental analysis of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) was also studied with EDX technique (Fig. S1, see supporting information). The scaffolds of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 and MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) were confirmed with existence of Pd, O, N, C, Cl, Cr and Cr, N, O, C atoms, respectively. Also, scattering elementals on the surface of the catalyst were explored by SEM-elemental mapping (Fig. S2, see supporting information). The figure shows that all types of elements are well dispersed over the surface of catalyst. In another investigation, morphology of catalyst was examined by SEM technique. As shown in Fig. 3 , particles morphology of the catalysts is tetrahedral. In addition, morphology structure of catalyst was studied more closely using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrograph in Fig. 4 . Therefore, catalyst is corner-shared tetrahedral [67]. Also, TEM images confirm the presence of Pd at the surface of MOFs. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) and catalyst were presented in Fig. 5 (a, c). Appearance of small hysteresis loops for MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) means that this catalyst has a small number of mesopores. The hysteresis loop disappeared for MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 indicating the presence of just microspores for this catalyst. The calculated BET surface areas of MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) and MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 are 1505 and 1029 m2g−1, and their corresponding total pore volumes are 1.253 and 0.735 cm3g−1, respectively. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution plots indicate that most of the pores for both samples are microspores, Fig. 5(b, d). All these textural data show that by deposition of Pd on MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC) some of the pores were occupied or blocked leading to decrease in textural parameters. Fig. 6a shows the XPS survey spectrum of the prepared catalyst. This spectrum shows that the catalyst includes C, O, N, Cr and Pd elements. High resolution XPS spectra of C, O, N and Pd are shown in Fig. 6 b–e. Nitrogen (1s) and oxygen (1s) XPS spectra show individual peaks with the binding energy at 399 and 531 eV, respectively, which are in agreement with their accepted values [68]. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of C (1s) shows a high intensity peak with the binding energy of 285 eV and a shoulder at 288 eV; the high intensity peak belongs to the carbon bonded to carbon while the low intensity peak belongs to carbon bonded to nitrogen. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Pd (3d) shows two peaks at binding energy of 337.9 and 343.3 eV, respectively, belonging to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2. These two peaks reveal the presence of Pd(II) at the surface of prepared catalyst [69]. For optimization of ipso-nitration of aryl-X (X: boronic acids, chlorides, halides and trifluoromethanesulfonate), the reaction of iodobenzene (1 mmol, 0.204 g) with MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2/NaNO2 as a model of reaction was tested in the presence of various amount of (MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2), solvents and temperatures (Table 1 ). The best conditions were determined to be n-butanol as solvent under reflux condition (Table 1, entry 4). Besides, other solvents such as EtOH, CH2Cl2, CH3CN, 1,4-Dioxane and solvent-free condition produced little nitro materials (Table 1, entries 1–14). The model reaction was also tested by using several nitrating systems such as KNO3, KNO2, Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, [Msim]NO3, MIL-101-NH2/NaNO2, MIL-101-N(PC)/NaNO2 and PdCl2/NaNO2. The obtained results show that the reaction conditions did not improve (Table 1, entries 15–22). It was found that TBAOH as a phase transfer catalyst increases the solubility of the reaction mixture in n-butanol and gives highest isolated yield. After optimizing the ipso-nitration reaction, the scopes and restrictions of the presented methodology were examined to synthesis a wide range of nitro-olefins and aromatic compounds, respectively (Table 2 ). Firstly, various arylboronic acid compounds containing (bearing electron-donating and electron-withdrawing) tags and halide were reacted with MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2/ NaNO2 as nitrating system to give target nitro aromatic compounds in good yields (Table 2, entries 1–9). Having explained the strategy on carbocyclic acid derivatives (olefins and arenes) were also investigated. Firstly, benzoyl chloride derivatives containing (bearing electron-donating and electron-withdrawing) groups were synthesized according to the previously reported procedure [62]. For this purpose, we applied MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2/ NaNO2 as a nitrating system for nitration of the mentioned starting materials to produce the desired nitroolefins and nitroarenes in good yield (Table 2, entries 10–22). In the next section, we decided to investigate the preparation of nitro aromatic compounds by reaction of phenol derivatives. Firstly, we have synthesized phenyl trifluoromethanesulfonate containing (bearing electron-donating and electron-withdrawing) tags and halide according to the previously reported method [63]. Then, we applied them at the ipso-nitration reaction by using the above-mentioned nitrating system to give nitroarenes in good yields (Table 2, entries 23–34). Besides, various aryl halide derivatives were reacted with the described nitrating system to give target nitro compounds in good yield (Table 2, entries 35–47). Chemo and homoselective organic functional group interconversion are our research interests [78-88]. To the best of our knowledge, the chemoselective organic reaction concept will be used for the reaction in which two functional groups are susceptible to one conversion, so one of them is more active than the other. In this situation, we can use the equivalent number for selective reaction. A homoselective reaction will be used, when two same functional groups are present within a single molecule and one is converted to a new functional group (Schemes 4 and 5 ). In this regard, we have checked out the chemo and homoselectivity of the nitration reaction for preparation of nitro aromatic compounds via ipso-nitration reaction, and found the order of reactivity of starting materials for Ar-X is X: B(OH)2> OTf> halogens (I>Br>Cl)> COCl. Therefore, different starting materials (Ar-X) which have two different electrophilic sites (Br and/or Cl, COOH and COCl, and so on) on the benzene moiety were used for this purpose. We know that these substrates may be nitrated via chemo and homoselective reaction (Scheme 4 and 5). Scince we have not performed any mechanistic investigation, it is reasonable to assume a mechanism similar to other Ulllmann-type reactions [50]. In a purposed mechanism for ipso-nitration reaction, a plausible catalytic cycle is proposed in Scheme 6 . The catalytic species can be formed in situ using MIL-101(Cr)-N(PC)-PdCl2 as palladium source. In the first stage, Pd(0) was prepared from palladium precursor and reacted with Ar-X to give intermediate (I) via an oxidative addition, followed by the X-nitrite exchange reaction to prepare intermediate (II). In the next step, reductive elimination of intermediate (II) afforded the desired products (Scheme 6). Conclusion In conclusion, the presented nitrating system was successfully applied for selective nitration of aryl boronic acids, aroyl chlorides, aryl halides and aryl trifluoromethanesulfonate. Cleaner reaction profile, better atom economy and minimum by-product formation, good to excellent yields, short reaction times, and diversity of ipso-nitration reaction are major advantages of described work. In contrast to some of the previously reported methods, our presented methodology provides a convenient approach for the preparation of many pharmaceutical starting materials without the involvement of directing groups. coredata.dc:description: A new selective nitration methodology is reported in which MOFs/sodium nitrite is used. A wide range of compounds such as boronic acids, aryl halides, aryl trifluoromethanesulfonate and aroyl chlorides were nitrated in the presence of a catalytic amount of palladium (Pd) embedded into MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 as a porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The described method provides a beneficial and convenient strategy for chemo and homoselective ipso-nitration reaction. In contrast to the previously reported methodologies, acid nitric (HNO3) was not used in the course of the nitration reaction. The presented method was applied for the ipso-nitration of a broad range of compounds (47 samples) under mild conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic chemo and homoselective ipso-nitration under mild condition
